results.notes:
Growing with mixed conifers @ ~ 6000 ft.
Caps up to 10.6 cm across.
Stems with lilac hues on lower portion
5% KOH light reddish on cap and flesh.
Spores appeared to be of two shapes. The simple elliptical/elongate and many with a more stretched out shape, and both only slightly rough.
The smaller spores were ~ 9 X 5 microns while the larger ones were ~ 11-14 X 5 microns with a fairly long apiculus.
Odor was not strong.

results.notes:
1-3mm yellow cups on moist well-rotted wood – possibly yellow birch – along Potomac River on MD side. Outside of cup pale yellow compared to bright yellow on edge and inside of cup, inside of cup turning orange upon drying. Microscopy reveals relatively immature individuals.
Note: The thickness of the ascocarp, the blunt thickness of the edge, the pale to whitish outside, tendency to turn orange when dry make me question whether this can be bisporella.

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 146027778 on January 7, 2023.

results.location_name: Silver Fork Rd., Eldorado National Forest, El Dorado Co., California, USA

results.notes:
Two fruiting bodies growing side-by-side in the middle of a sandy road that suddenly turned into a large and deep sand pit. Basically, these were growing in pure, free-flowing sand, like one usually finds on an ocean beach or in a coastal sand dune. I couldn’t think of a harsher local environment to support the growth of any mycorrhizal fungus, let alone such large fruiting bodies — a desert-like open area, totally exposed to the sun, and lacking adequate levels of both moisture and nutrients. Only the caps were showing above the surface, the stipes were largely (60-80%) buried deep in the substrate. I simply inserted my hands up to my wrists into the sand and scooped them up. Both pitch pine and oaks were in the vicinity.

Description:
> Off-white, plano-convex to planar cap of the older specimen is 10 cm wide and 1 cm thick in the middle, partially covered with the peeling, thin and uniform layer of a felted, cream-colored volval material; there are no visible warts or raised patches of UV; the exposed cuticle below is bald and smooth, but not shiny. The younger fruitbody’s plano-convex cap is totally and evenly covered with the the off-white UV material. The cap margins are appendiculate and decorated with torn and ragged pieces of a PV.
> The gills are 1.1-1.2 cm wide (older fb), cream to ochraceous-cream, sub-distant, with plentiful lamellulae of various lengths; the short gills are rounded sub-truncate to attenuate.
> The stipe of the older specimen is 12.5 cm long, more or less equal, with a flaring apex (2.6 cm wide), becoming slightly constricted directly below (1.9 cm wide min), then gradually expanding from mid-point toward the base (2.5 cm wide max), and getting constricted again in the base (2.3 cm), thus giving the impression of a bulb, whereas there is actually none (see pix). The stipe of the younger fruitbody is sub-clavate, terminating in a pointy but short turnip-shaped bulb (see pix). The torn remnants of the partial veil are apical. The are no visible remnants of the UV anywhere on the stipe; perhaps it has the same consistency as the UV on the cap, and was easily brushed off with the sand.
> The flesh is solid, firm and off-white, beginning to erratically stain cream to pale yellow in the stipe and at the juncture with the cap a few minutes following exposure to air.
> The odor is stinky-sweet, like a mixture of dried fish and gym socks, and strong.

Spore Data:
> Mounted in Melzer’s and measured in profile/side-view (suprahilar appendage to the side).
> [40/1/1]: L x W = 9.4~16.3 (-17.2) x 3.7~4.7 (-5.3) μm, L’ x W’ = 12.1 × 4.2 μm; Q = (2.28-) 2.36~3.50 (-3.70), Q’ = 2.85.
> Amyloid, smooth, hyaline, thin-walled; equilateral and oblong in face-view (dorsal/ventral); slightly to perceptibly inequilateral in side-view (dorsiventral), ranging from perfectly oblong/equal to being clavate toward either end or sometimes constricted in the middle or toward the distal end, sometimes with a shallow suprahilar plage; cylindric to baciliform (7 spores with Q = 2.28-2.50, 11 spores with Q = 2.50-2.75, 9 spores with Q = 2.75-3.00, 6 spores with Q = 3.00-3.25, and 6 spores with Q = 3.25-3.50).

Discussion: After transcribing my notes and getting additional details from the pix for the above description, I suddenly had a deja vu. A targeted search of my Pine Barrens observations led to obs 208566 from Wharton State Forest from 2 years ago. I think is the same taxon based on the morphology, the peculiar odor and the spore size and shape. A. subsolitaria is a possibility, though again the observed Q’ is quite high, with a substantial number of baciliform spores (see the comments in 208566).
DNA sequence results and discussion (posted on 27-Mar-23):
This collection was sampled for LSU by Dr. Kudzma. The amplified region is between LSU0F and LR7 primers. The amplicon was sequenced with a combination of two forward reads — LSU0F and LR3R. The obtained sequence is a joined contig of 1410 bps. The sequence has been uploaded to this post.
The legible portion of the sequence starts from the ITS4 primer area and ends at the LR7 primer, which was seen and edited out. I was barely able to connect the two long reads near the LR3 primer area because of the subpar peak shape at the 3’ end of the LSU0F read. Both reads had a 1-base frameshift heterogeneity, which required extensive correction of base calling at the end of the LSU0F read, but, thankfully, not so much in the other read.
A BLASTn search if the full-sequence gave nothing closer than 92.8% in pairwise similarity. A BLASTn of the forward read (the first 672 bps of the sequence) gave accession #MH620285 derived from a collection made in Florida as the top hit at 99.3% similarity. There is no question it is the same species. The 2nd from top hit was only ~93% similar. This Lepidella may look a bit generic, but it’s a very distinct phylogenetic species. LSU is a good barcoding locus for Lepidellas because they are a very old lineage of Amanita. The ITS would also be a good barcode as long as sequencing doesn’t involve Sanger methodology. This is because Lepidellas almost always have heteromorphic ITS regions.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_1090/2017_DSC9185

Habitat: moderately inclined mountain slope, southeast aspect; mixed wood edge, under Ostrya carpinifolia and Picea abies; calcareous ground; dry place, mostly in shade; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 640 m (2.100 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: in moss over forest soil, also on a thin moss layer over rock.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča; next to the trail from abandoned farm house Strgulc, Soča 48 to Planina Na skalah, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comment: Growing in groups of several fruitbodies and solitary; more than 20 pilei altogether; cap diameter 4.5 – 8 cm, pilei trama up to 10 mm thick, gills layer up to 3.5 mm thick; gills crowded, up to 130 gills per 3600 were counted; gills layer can be easily separated from trama; bruising brown-red when handled; cutis strong, easily pealing; stipes up to 6.5 cm long with diameter up to 16 mm; longitudinally fibrous, not hollow, tapering toward the base; picked mushrooms turn entirely to brown-reddish with time; SP ochre-brown, oac817.

Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Sony ILCE6000 / Carl Zeiss Vario-Tessar E 16-70mm/ f4

results.notes:
This collection was actually made by my cousin who sent me pictures. The first name that I arrived at for it was Stropharia umbonatescens but I soon realized that Protostropharia luteonitens is apparently the preferred name for the former species now.

With only having pictures to go on, I feel like all of the macroscopic characteristics line up well. The only thing I’m unsure about is the habitat. I don’t know what type of wood chips are shown in the pictures and I believe I read that the species I’m suggesting is coprophilous anyway. The one specimen shown on one of the under cap shots definitely appears to be growing off one of the wood chips though.

results.notes: These were located just a couple feet off the road in a front yard. I initially thought they had to be something else, something terrestrial. There was absolutely no wood that they were growing on at all (at least as much as I could tell). A small hard mass was at the base of one of the larger stems which I thought might involve a piece of wood but I was able to cut through it fairly easily with a knife. I believe it was just a mycelial mass. I’ve read that these can have the appearance of being terrestrial if they were growing on underground or very well decayed wood. I just found it odd that I located no wood at all. They also had to be a good number of feet from the nearest standing tree. One thing I can note is that they took a good bit of wrestling to pick. I usually have an easier time picking a mushroom if it is indeed terrestrial.

results.notes:
In grass a few yards away from a tree line of mostly oak, growing in scattered groups and clusters.

The photographs will probably be more telling about the appearance than my shaky description.

These have brilliantly colored stems and sometimes the caps that range from rosey red to purple tones.

The cap flesh seemed to stain pink, the pore surface and tubes also stained a blue/black, it appeared to also stain alittle bluish in the inner stem area, but this was extremely light.

Maybe these are B. inedulis?

results.notes:
Growing at edge of trail in open woods, predominantly hardwood.
Cap. Largest ca. 2.5-3” diameter; white with gray center; numerous warts.
Gills. Free; white; close; short gills frequent.
Stipe. Largest ca. 0.5” at apex, narrowing slightly, then increasing in diameter to large base. No evidence of volva; delicate, ‘frilly’ annulus; smooth above annulus; ‘wooly’ below annulus.
Odor. No distinctive odor

Thanks to Ken Barbagallo for ID

results.notes: Small white mushroom growing most commonly in living or dead moss (Sphagnum and other species), but also found on the ground in bits of other plant debris, including small pieces of birch bark, deciduous leaves and tiny rotting twigs (but not on logs). Caps very thin, largest 2 cm but the rest 3-10 mm, oyster-shaped, edges sometimes becoming frilly with maturity. Smooth gills, very short or no stem. “Fuzzy” with mycelium at attachment point to substrate. Spore print white. Spores tear drop shaped, (4.4)5-6.8(8.9) x (3)3.1-4.3(5.6). Means 5.8 (SD 0.6) x 3.7 (SD 0.4), n = 113.

results.notes: For my 500th observation here at MO I thought I’d dig back to my roots and share some of my old Psilocybe cubensis pics from south Louisiana. These pics were taken over several years (2014-2016) in 2 separate cattle fields. Unfortunately these pics were not only taken with a camera phone, but had to be retrieved from the cloud in low resolution, so the quality is not what I would like it to be, but it’s all I have left of those hunts. This was the mushroom that started my mycological journey 10 years ago, and it seemed fitting to make my 500th post something memorable.

results.notes:
Observado en Cerro El Venado, altura aprox 500 msnm, creciendo sobre madera; bosque húmedo pre montano (bh-PM), precipitación mínima de 15 – 25 mm en los meses de enero y diciembre, precipitación máxima 350 mm y 300 mm en los meses de mayo, junio y julio, con menos de 60 mm de lluvia en el mes más seco y precipitación anual superior a 1270 mm. Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. Temperatura media anual mayor de 20 °C, con una estación seca y una lluviosa bien definidas (Bustamante, et al 2013). Yopal cuenta con una extensión de 2595 km, Altura media: 390 msnm y una Población Total de 146 204 hab. (2005)

-Cuenta con valores mínimos de humedad relativa a inicio del año (65%), y valores más altos en junio, julio, agosto y septiembre (90-85%), pluviosidad entre 2000 y 4000 mm y temperatura promedio mayor de 24 °C, con amplitud de temperatura máxima de 8 °C, (DANE, 1999; Castro & Sosa, 2017)

-Se observan arboles representativos como Yarumo (Cecropia spp), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_460/2010_IMG2482
Picture file names: from Amanita-vaginata_raw_1 to Amanita-vaginata_raw_7.

Habitat: Mixed wood, mainly hardwoods, almost flat terrain, cretaceous clastic rock (flysh) bedrock, quite humid place, in shade; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 8-10 deg C, elevation 400 m (1,280 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: soil.

Place: Bovec basin, west of town Bovec, next to the trail from Bovec to village Plužna, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comment: Since this find had almost white hut (normally it is supposed to be some kind of gray, grayish-brown) it may eventually be named also Amanita vaginata var. alba (De Seynes) Gillet. But the grayish buckle poses problems. Var. alba is supposed to be completely white.

Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5

results.notes:
In mixed woods, primarily eastern white pine, beech, ash. Measuring ~10 cm in height, with cap approx ~ 6cm in width. Pileus olivaceous brown, with some dark grey patches at center, not easily removable. Margins striate. Gills free, off-white, with numerous short gills of varying lengths. Stipe widening towards base, stuffed with cottony fibrils. Dark grey volval remnants in cottony bands near base, with white material covering extreme rounded end of stipe.

Updated: Half of material mailed to RET at his request on 10/3/17. Other half retained in personal herbarium as part of PVMA Mycoflora project.
